tiagobandeirabr wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> I was looking in the junit.org website, and i read the following
> affirmation:
> "if a method doesn't return a value, it will have some side effect.
> Actually, if it doesn't return a value AND doesn't have a side
> effect, it isn't doing anything."
> 
> I have some methods in my software that don't return nothing, but
> they have some side effects.
> 
> Very well... I wrote my test class, and i saw that the side effects
> occured as i planned.
> 
> I create a new method, without return, that basically verifies some
> conditions, and so it call the other methods (already tested) in
> acordance with these conditions.
> 
> So, my doubt is the following one:
> 
> How i make the test of this new method without remaking the test
> already done?

This is exactly what happens in a design with too much coupling between 
objects: when you test the "invoking" method, you find you have to do as 
much work (and more) as you did to test the "invoked" method.

The simplest solution is to break this dependency with an interface 
between the invoking method and the invoked method. This way you can 
substitute in your tests a simpler version of the invoked method that 
doesn't make you re-test something you already tested.

For more information, look at _JUnit Recipes_, chapter 2 and the book 
_Working Effectively with Legacy Code_.
-- 
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
